timeline.body:
I haven't been conquered by this kind of method. 

We're having them in more and more test classes, leading me to the question: why don't we want it in the sources for all usage?

They can change from one test to another, which doesn't help when reviewing code as we can't be sure that method does the thing we're used to/expect to. Furthermore, I think it's surprising to have code which doesn't use this method in the same test (we can see it in the `@Before`). Surprising because the method has the same name than the core session one and because it's not coherent with rest of test.

When it comes to use it, we often need to put a comment in front of, in the end we don't benefit from the saved line this method gives.
For instance, I would prefer the "old way" in the text block below:
```java
// create a simple hierarchy (domain <- DOCUMENT_NAME <- ANOTHER_DOCUMENT_NAME)
DocumentModel mainDocModel = createDocument(parentDocModel, ANOTHER_DOCUMENT_NAME);
```
```java
DocumentModel mainDocModel = session.createDocumentModel("/domain/anyFile", ANOTHER_DOCUMENT_NAME, "File");
mainDocModel = session.createDocument(parentDocModel);
```
I'm in favor of removing this kind of method and doing light and explicit things.

Note: the example above highlights the fact you're creating a `File` under another `File` which is permitted since the comment improvement but I'm not sure this is what we want to do here, we may want to do something closer to reality.
